results.snippet: WHAT do you get when you take the din out of dinner? Well, you get something like the Council of Fashion Designers of America's awards dinner last Thursday night, held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Temple of Dendur. The cocktail party started...
results.lead_paragraph: WHAT do you get when you take the din out of dinner? Well, you get something like the Council of Fashion Designers of America's awards dinner last Thursday night, held at the Metropolitan Museum of Art's Temple of Dendur. The cocktail party started with great energy, much of it supplied by Diane Brill, the downtown fashion designer, who delighted the assembled uptown group by wearing a black strapless dress with a strategically placed rhinestone question-mark pin. ''Who is that girl?'' asked Carolina and Reinaldo Herrera and Kenneth Jay Lane in unison. Then the dinner fell flat, with many of the city's top designers not showing up. Worse, there was no music so that at one point it was quiet enough to hear people crunching their couscous. Still, some who attended, including Geraldine Stutz, the president of Henri Bendel, said that the awards, which began as an alternative to the Cotys, could work with more support from the fashion community. And there was some new fashion to be seen, most notably on Marina Schiano, who accepted the women's design award for Calvin Klein. She wore a new Veronica Lake haircut, a new floor-length black shirtdress and no jewelry, a taste of Klein's held- back look for next fall.

results.snippet: Few seasoned Georgia politicians will venture a guess as to the outcome of the Democratic Presidential primary in this state on Tuesday. Those willing to make a forecast said the contest appeared to be between Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and...
results.lead_paragraph: Few seasoned Georgia politicians will venture a guess as to the outcome of the Democratic Presidential primary in this state on Tuesday. Those willing to make a forecast said the contest appeared to be between Senator Gary Hart of Colorado and Walter F. Mondale, with Senator John Glenn of Ohio and the Rev. Jesse Jackson as imponderable elements. Mr. Mondale's forces in Georgia, regarded as not nearly so well organized as in the Northeast, have tried to make sure they get black voters backing their candidate to the polls while at the same time trying not to activate Jackson supporters. The strategy is based on the firm belief that Mr. Jackson's strengh lies among younger, lower-income blacks while Mr. Mondale's is among middle- class blacks 35 years old and over.

results.snippet: ATLANTA    F OR months, Walter F. Mondale played peacemaker on the campaign trail, warning his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination that attacks on one another would only hurt the party's chances of beating President Reagan. But last...
results.lead_paragraph: ATLANTA F OR months, Walter F. Mondale played peacemaker on the campaign trail, warning his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination that attacks on one another would only hurt the party's chances of beating President Reagan. But last week Mr. Mondale abruptly shelved his speak-no-evil politics. From Boston to Tampa, he denounced Senator Gary Hart as a cold, aloof newcomer who would betray the Democrats' bedrock ideals of fairness and compassion. ''Where's the heart? Where's the guts?'' Mr. Mondale exclaimed as he pressed his argument that Mr. Hart has severe character deficiencies. ''It is not just a horse race,'' he added later in the week. ''This has become a battle for the soul of the Democratic Party and for the future of our country.'' It was also a battle to save the Mondale campaign from total collapse. Mondale strategists acknowledged that the attacks were a last-resort effort to slow the advance of Mr. Hart, who since the Iowa precinct caucuses on Feb. 20 has wiped out Mr. Mondale's standing as the party's front-runner.

results.snippet: Candidates for the Democratic nomination for President campaigned intensely today for an important electoral week as Gary Hart continued a series of gains by easily defeating Walter F. Mondale in the Wyoming caucuses.    The candidates' efforts...

byline.original: By HOWELL RAINES, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Candidates for the Democratic nomination for President campaigned intensely today for an important electoral week as Gary Hart continued a series of gains by easily defeating Walter F. Mondale in the Wyoming caucuses. The candidates' efforts were spurred by the imminence of a nationally televised debate here Sunday that Mr. Mondale's advisers regard as the most important of four such events this year. Coming after a week in which Mr. Hart consistently gained support across the South, the debate is regarded by Democratic strategists as Mr. Mondale's best and perhaps his final chance to slow Senator Hart's advance before Tuesday. On that day, voters in nine states will join in a round of primaries and caucuses that might dramatically narrow the field of five contenders. Senator Hart's victory in Wyoming was his fourth in a row over Mr. Mondale. With 21 of the state's 23 counties reporting, Senator Hart had 2,086 votes, or 60 percent, to 1,242 for Mr. Mondale, or 36 percent.

headline.main: DEMOCRATS FOCUS ON SOUTH AS HART ANSWERS CRITICISM

results.snippet: Four of the five Democratic Presidential aspirants campaigned in the South today as nine states across the nation prepared for a potentially crucial set of primary elections and caucuses on Tuesday.     While Senator Gary Hart of Colorado answered...

byline.original: By PHIL GAILEY, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: Four of the five Democratic Presidential aspirants campaigned in the South today as nine states across the nation prepared for a potentially crucial set of primary elections and caucuses on Tuesday. While Senator Gary Hart of Colorado answered fresh criticism of his campaign from Sunday's debate, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale said that ''this incredible momentum'' for Mr. Hart was ebbing. He vowed to continue his fight for the nomination ''clear through California if necessary.'' Mr. Mondale challenged Mr. Hart to a debate before each of the remaining primaries, but the Senator declined. ''It would be the height of arrogance of me to accept'' as long as other candidates remained in the race, Mr. Hart said. He said he would debate Mr. Mondale if the others were also invited.

results.snippet: Marc Garneau, a 35-year-old commander in the Canadian Navy, has been chosen as a payload specialist on the October space shuttle mission, officials said today. He will be the first Canadian to fly in space.
results.lead_paragraph: Marc Garneau, a 35-year-old commander in the Canadian Navy, has been chosen as a payload specialist on the October space shuttle mission, officials said today. He will be the first Canadian to fly in space.

headline.main: ADVISERS TO GLENN SAY HE WILL QUIT DEMOCRATIC RACE

results.snippet: John Glenn, once considered the principal challenger to Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination, plans to withdraw from the race, top campaign aides said today.    Senator Glenn, whose campaign is more than $2 million in debt,...

byline.original: By DAVID SHRIBMAN, Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: John Glenn, once considered the principal challenger to Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination, plans to withdraw from the race, top campaign aides said today. Senator Glenn, whose campaign is more than $2 million in debt, has scheduled a news conference here on Friday morning to announce his decision. His aides said he was not likely to endorse either of the two leading candidates, Senator Gary Hart of Colorado or former Vice President Mondale. ''Almost all the advice went in the direction of withdrawing,'' said one of the Ohio Senator's aides, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, ''but the decision was his.''

results.snippet: For John Glenn, the end came quietly, with no brass bands, no chants from supporters, not even a request for an autograph. There were only a news conference in a Congressional hearing room and a few words that were just short of melancholy.    As...
results.lead_paragraph: For John Glenn, the end came quietly, with no brass bands, no chants from supporters, not even a request for an autograph. There were only a news conference in a Congressional hearing room and a few words that were just short of melancholy. As recently as mid-February, Senator Glenn was regarded as the most serious challenger to former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and the Democrat with the best chance of defeating President Reagan. Today, having failed to do better than a weak second in the first dozen political tests of 1984, he withdrew from the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination. ''I'd like nothing better than to stay in this race and compete in every primary, every caucus, and win the nomination of my party,'' he said an hour before he climbed into his own plane to fly to Columbus, Ohio, ''but in the past few weeks it became clear that none of these things is going to happen.'' The removal of Mr. Glenn, who has served Ohio in the Senate for a decade, does more than winnow the number of Democratic candidates to three. It represents rejection of an American hero and is perhaps the most compelling sub-plot in a drama with only three stars now: Senator Gary Hart, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Mr. Mondale.

headline.main: UPSTATE BOY IS YOUNGEST TO GET A PERFECT S.A.T. MATH SCORE

results.snippet: A seventh-grader here who became the youngest person to score a perfect 800 on the mathematics section of the Scholastic Aptitude Test says it really wasn't hard: ''I just figured it out logically.''   The pupil, 12-year-old Matthew Van Vlack, got...
results.lead_paragraph: A seventh-grader here who became the youngest person to score a perfect 800 on the mathematics section of the Scholastic Aptitude Test says it really wasn't hard: ''I just figured it out logically.'' The pupil, 12-year-old Matthew Van Vlack, got a perfect score on the college-entrance examination's math section three months ago at age 11 even though many of the questions covered material he had never studied. ''What makes it more remarkable is that it happened the first time he took the test,'' said Dr. Julian Stanley, a psychology professor at Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore.

headline.main: MITTERRAND BIDS U.S. NOT RILE MOSCOW

results.snippet: President Francois Mitterrand, at the end of two days of talks with Administration officials, warned today against ''creating new causes of dissension'' in East- West relations at a time when the Soviet Union may be reassessing its position on...
results.lead_paragraph: President Francois Mitterrand, at the end of two days of talks with Administration officials, warned today against ''creating new causes of dissension'' in East- West relations at a time when the Soviet Union may be reassessing its position on arms control talks. Mr. Mitterrand met with President Reagan over breakfast this morning after a state banquet and hourlong talks on Thursday. A senior Administration official told reporters the two had agreed that the Soviet Union would be welcomed back to renewed arms reduction talks but that the West should not offer special inducements to get the talks started again.

results.snippet: An Air Force general who has directed the space shuttle program was appointed today to manage a program to explore the feasibility of building a space-based defense against nuclear ballistic missiles.     Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson, associate...
results.lead_paragraph: An Air Force general who has directed the space shuttle program was appointed today to manage a program to explore the feasibility of building a space-based defense against nuclear ballistic missiles. Lieut. Gen. James A. Abrahamson, associate director for space flight at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, was named by Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger to be program manager of what the Ragan Administration calls the ''strategic defense initiative,'' a program suggested a year ago by President Reagan. General Abrahamson will begin his new duties on April 15 after the nation's 11th space shuttle flight, scheduled to start April 6.

headline.main: FIRST SPACE TEST OF YOGA SET FOR INDIAN ON SOVIET MISSION

results.snippet: India's first man in space is to perform yoga while strapped to sensitive instruments that measure weightlessness and motion sickness, Soviet space officials said today.    The Indian astronaut, Rakesh Sharma, 35 years old, will join two Soviet...
results.lead_paragraph: India's first man in space is to perform yoga while strapped to sensitive instruments that measure weightlessness and motion sickness, Soviet space officials said today. The Indian astronaut, Rakesh Sharma, 35 years old, will join two Soviet astronauts on the eight-day mission beginning Tuesday, the officials said at a news conference. The Soyuz T-10 spacecraft is to be launched from Soviet Central Asia carrying Mr. Sharma, Col. Yuri V. Malyshev, 42, and Gennadi M. Strekalov, 43. Two days later, it is to dock with the Salyut 7 orbiting space station, where three astronauts have been working since Feb. 8. The Soviet-Indian crew is to return to earth April 10.
